That is false. Everything is technically a "number" and Thresh is just as dependent on him as anyone else.

You can increase his CDs, making his abilities available to him less often so misusing them is more punishing. 
You can increase his mana costs, reduce his mana pool or mana regeneration, so whiffing abilities is more punishing.
You can make him squishier, or slower, so he relies more on good positioning to survive.
You can lower the range on abilities, forcing him to commit more.
You can lower the duration the lantern waits for you to click it, lowering the window of opportunity.
You can straight up remove things from him, like the slow after getting hit by Flay.

Thresh is not that special champion who's magically "immune" to getting significant nerfs. He's just not getting them because Riot likes him being a top pick because #lcsplays.

Straight up removing things from him would not be a numbers change, it'd be a mechanics change and that's exactly what Mike was talking about.

Thresh has so much utility that he could do 0 damage and still be a contested pick. There are only two outcomes for kits like that:

1. Thresh gets a few number nerfs that mean jack all and continues to dominate
2. Thresh gets a lot of number nerfs and has such high cooldowns, high mana costs, and/or reduced CC duration that he is unplayable

He didn't have the highest win rate.  His win rate was barely above 50% (11W 10L), same as it is in most elos.  For all the complaining people do about Thresh he has consistently stayed around the 50% win rate patch after patch.  He's strong in the right hands but definitely not overpowered.
How would you nerf Thresh?

People complain about his damage a lot, if he ACTUALLY has good damage, that would be a place to nerf him without affecting his core strengths (playmaking).  Same with Tahm, both of them are designed in a way where they really don't need to do significant damage to be useful (unlike say Leona, because she has to go ham to land anything except ult, without her passive damage her teammates wouldn't be able to kill the person she's locking down and she would just die uselessly).

On the other hand, if the complainers are full of shit and he actually does Braum level damage or lower already while being squishier than the true tank supports, then there isn't as much room to do something like that.

Well, according to champion.gg comparing his damage average to other supports... the only support that does _less_ damage than him on average is Janna. He's outdamaged by tank supports like Braum and Leona, and does significantly less damage than Tahm Kench.

Thresh is chosen entirely for his raw utility and play making ability - he's very commonly chosen for those reasons. Just because he's popular doesn't mean he needs nerfs, it means that the overall perception by the player base is that he a supports that's generally useful all the time.

Thresh is far from broken. To give a example between the differents:

* {{champion:223}} 5x (4W 1L)= 80% winrate (note that this was the prenerfed Tahm) ; Banrate 8 times
* {{champion:412}} 21x (11W 10L)= 52% winrate (this was the prenerfed Thresh, {{item:3035}} only penetrates bonus armor) ; Banrate 6 times

Thresh was always a support that provided peel unknown by previous designed supports. Notice that all support after Thresh besides {{champion:432}} has this high pickrate ({{champion:201}} {{champion:223}}).

Add this point Thresh is fine, every time riot changes something it's a indirect nerf to him. He might have a lot of options. He's never the best add something and every time a new support get released his loses a strength into one of this area's. Before {{champion:201}} we had the shielding Thresh build. Before {{champion:432}} we had the Talis gank assist Thresh build. Not because it was the best build. Before {{champion:223}} was picked Thresh as peel support for any hyper carry. We didn't picked it because he was strong in that area. We just picked it because it was the best option add that moment.

TL:DR {{champion:412}} was the first in the so called new generation of supports.
I, for one, welcome our new support overlords.

Why?

This seems more a matter of perception than anything else. "Being chosen a lot" is not a legitimate reason for nerfs; it means he's generally considered useful, vs more niche or specialist supports.

If you think he needs to be nerfed, you should at the very least be able to say where he's overpowered an needs nerfs... but you don't. You simply have a nebulous assertion that "he's the most chosen support, therefore he must need nerfs in some way".

Every marksman in the game will buy {{item:3006}} as opposed to any other shoe choice; clearly that item must be OP and in massive need of nerfs.
